Introduction

Peritonsillar abscess (PTA) is a localized collection of pus in the peritonsillar space between the tonsil and pharyngeal muscles.  It typically occurs as a complication of tonsillitis.  Symptoms include fever, severe sore throat, trismus, and a muffled voice.  Unilateral tonsillar/palatal enlargement with uvular deviation to the unaffected side is the classic finding on examination.  Treatment involves abscess drainage and antibiotic therapy.

Pathophysiology



PTA occurs most commonly in adolescents and young adults following an episode of acute tonsillitis.  There are 2 proposed mechanisms of abscess formation:



  • Infection begins within the tonsil, then bacteria spread into the loose connective tissue of the peritonsillar space.  This progresses to peritonsillar cellulitis and eventually pus collects to form an abscess.
  • Tonsillar inflammation causes obstruction of salivary glands located superior to the tonsils.  Gland obstruction promotes bacterial overgrowth, which then infects the peritonsillar space and ultimately results in an abscess.


Peritonsillar infections are largely thought to be polymicrobial.  Cultures typically grow group A Streptococcus, Staphylococcus aureus, and respiratory anaerobes (eg, Fusobacteria).

Risk factors



  • Recurrent tonsillitis
  • Adolescence and young adulthood
  • Immunocompromised status
  • Poor oral hygiene
  • Smoking

Clinical presentation



Typical symptoms of PTA:



  • Severe sore throat
  • Difficulty swallowing
  • Fever
  • Ipsilateral referred otalgia (ear pain)
  • Decreased oral intake


Characteristic examination findings:



  • Muffled or "hot potato" voice:  The abscess decreases the space in the posterior pharynx, leading to decreased vocal resonance and the classic muffled, "hot potato" voice.
  • Unilateral swelling of the tonsil and/or posterior soft palate with uvula deviation (
    figure 1
    ):  Pus collection in the soft tissue of the palate leads to a visible, fluctuant bulge above the tonsil that pushes the uvula to the contralateral side.
  • Trismus:  Inflammation and spasm of the nearby pterygoid muscles lead to pain and difficulty opening the mouth.
  • Drooling:  Secretions accumulate due to increased pain with swallowing.

Diagnosis



The diagnosis of PTA is typically made based on history and characteristic physical examination findings.  Laboratory evaluation, which is not required for diagnosis, may help gauge the severity of illness and guide care.



  • Complete blood count (CBC) with differential can assess for elevated white blood cell (WBC) count with a predominance of neutrophils, which is common.
  • Metabolic panel can assess for dehydration and electrolyte abnormalities, which can occur in patients who have a significant decrease in oral intake.
  • Throat culture and culture of abscess fluid help identify the causative organism and direct antibiotic therapy.
  • Monospot test can be useful for ruling out infectious mononucleosis.
  • Blood cultures may be checked if evidence of septicemia is found.


Imaging is also not required for diagnosis but can be helpful in differentiating PTA from tonsillar cellulitis.  Imaging should be performed if there is concern for deeper infection such as retropharyngeal abscess.



  • Ultrasonography may be used during the initial evaluation to confirm the presence of PTA, which appears as a hypoechoic collection adjacent to the tonsil.
  • CT scan of the neck with contrast provides detailed visualization of PTA and evaluates surrounding structures for extent of infection, and is also helpful for surgical planning in complicated cases.

Differential diagnosis



  • Acute tonsillitis:  causes fever, sore throat, and difficulty swallowing.  However, the tonsillar swelling in tonsillitis is typically bilateral and symmetric, unlike the unilateral swelling and uvular deviation seen in PTA.  Trismus is also uncommon in tonsillitis.
  • Infectious mononucleosis (Epstein-Barr virus infection):  presents with fever, pharyngitis, and cervical lymphadenopathy.  Patients may have significant tonsillar enlargement with muffling of the voice, but a symmetric-appearing posterior oropharynx differentiates it from PTA.
  • Epiglottitis (
    figure 2
    ):  is characterized by the sudden onset of high fever, severe sore throat, muffled voice, and dysphagia; however, in epiglottitis the pharyngeal examination appears relatively normal.  Acute airway obstruction (eg, stridor, tripod positioning, drooling) is also more consistent with epiglottitis.
  • Retropharyngeal abscess (
    figure 3
    ):  symptoms include fever, odynophagia, muffled voice, and trismus, but this condition usually occurs in younger children (age 2-4) and is more likely to cause neck stiffness and pain with neck extension.
  • Ludwig angina (
    Ludwig angina
    ):  is characterized by cellulitis involving the submandibular, sublingual, and submental spaces; it may also cause fever, throat/mouth pain, dysphagia, and a muffled voice.  Examination findings, including tongue elevation and induration in the submandibular area, differentiate Ludwig angina from PTA.

Management



Patients with PTA (

figure 5
) are typically hospitalized for observation, pain management, hydration, and infection control.  Treatment includes:



  • Broad-spectrum IV antibiotics (eg, ampicillin-sulbactam, clindamycin) that target group A Streptococcus, S aureus, and respiratory anaerobes are started.  Patients may be switched to oral antibiotics once clinical improvement is observed.
  • Needle aspiration or incision and drainage of the abscess may be performed.
  • Tonsillectomy may be considered in lieu of abscess drainage in patients with recurrent episodes of PTA or with severe complications.
  • IV corticosteroids, although somewhat controversial, there is some evidence steroids decrease symptom severity and hospital length of stay.


Nontoxic patients with uncomplicated abscesses who are able to tolerate drainage under local anesthesia may be managed as outpatients.  However, they must also be able to maintain adequate hydration and swallow oral antibiotics.  Follow-up should be arranged within 24-36 hours.

Prognosis



With prompt diagnosis and appropriate management, the prognosis for PTA is generally favorable.  Complications such as airway obstruction, parapharyngeal extension, septicemia, and Lemierre syndrome (ie, septic thrombophlebitis of the internal jugular vein) can occur if left untreated.  Recurrence of PTA is possible, particularly in those with recurrent episodes of tonsillitis, and may warrant a complete tonsillectomy.

Summary



Peritonsillar abscess (
